result.markdown:
--- title: "Data Visualization
Sections 2.4 - 2.6" institute: "Department of Statistics and Data Science
STAT 202" logo: nu_logo.png format: revealjs: theme: [default, nu_theme.scss] chalkboard: theme: whiteboard toggleNotesButton: false menu: side: right code-line-numbers: false execute: message: false warning: false echo: true --- ## Today's goals {background-image="images_horst/ggplot2_masterpiece.png" background-size="400px" background-opacity="50%" background-position="85% 50%"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="60%"} 1. Create a linegraph 2. Create a histogram 3. Properly describe a linegraph and histogram 4. Facet graphs based on subgroups ::: ::: ::: {.absolute top="77%" left="85%" width="500"} ::: {style="opacity:0.75; font-size: 0.5em"} Artwork by @allison_horst ::: ::: ## 5NG#2: Linegraphs Linegraphs show the **relationship** between 2 **numerical** variables.
. . . The explanatory (x-axis) variable **must be of** sequential ordering.
. . . **Linegraph syntax in R:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data= my_data, mapping = aes(x = var1, y = var2)) + geom_line() ``` ::: ## 5NG#2: Linegraphs When describing linegraphs... ::: incremental - Look for pattern going from left to right. - Classify association as positive, negative, or no association. - Classify relationship as linear or non linear. - Check x and y scales to make sure they are appropriate. ::: ## 5NG#3: Histograms - Histograms are used to visualize the **distribution** of a single **numerical** variable. . . . - Histograms display **numerical** data by grouping data into bins of equal width. . . . - There is **no** 'y' position aesthetic for `geom_histogram()` because we are investigating a single variable. ## 5NG#3: Histograms **Histogram syntax in R:** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data= my_data, aes(x = var1)) + geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "blue", bins = 10) ``` :::
. . . There are 3 things we look and describe when inspecting a histogram: - shape (skew and modality) - center (mean or median) - spread (range, IQR, or standard deviation) . . . Not all distributions have a simple recognizable shape! ::: footer Type `colors()` in the **console** to view all possible colors. ::: ## 5NG#3: Histograms ::: {layout="[30,-5,30,-5,30],[30,-5,30,-5,30],[30,-5,30,-5,30]"} ![](images_lecture/fig_03unimodal1.png) ![](images_lecture/fig_03unimodal2.png) ![](images_lecture/fig_03unimodal3.png) ![](images_lecture/fig_03bimodal1.png) ![](images_lecture/fig_03bimodal3.png) ![](images_lecture/fig_03bimodal2.png) ![](images_lecture/fig_03multimodal1.png) ![](images_lecture/fig_03multimodal2.png) ![](images_lecture/fig_03uniform.png) ::: ## Example 1: Histogram bins {.scrollable .smaller} Which bin size is most appropriate and describe the distribution of penguin body mass. ::: {.absolute top="0%" left="90%" width="100"} ![](images_lecture/participate_icon.png) ::: ::: panel-tabset ## Bins = 7 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x=penguins$body_mass_g)) + geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "lightblue", bins = 7)+ labs(title = "Palmer Penguins Distribution of Body Mass", x = "Body Mass (g)") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec03_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Bins = 18 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x=penguins$body_mass_g)) + geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "lightblue", bins = 18)+ labs(title = "Palmer Penguins Distribution of Body Mass", x = "Body Mass (g)") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec03_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Bins = 29 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x=penguins$body_mass_g)) + geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "lightblue", bins = 29)+ labs(title = "Palmer Penguins Distribution of Body Mass", x = "Body Mass (g)") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec03_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: footer https://northwestern-university.shinyapps.io/lec03_histogram/ ::: ## Example 2: Histogram bins {.scrollable .smaller} ::: {.absolute top="0%" left="90%" width="100"} ![](images_lecture/participate_icon.png) ::: Which bin size is most appropriate and describe the distribution of penguin flipper length. ::: panel-tabset ## Bins = 15 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x=penguins$flipper_length_mm )) + geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "tomato1", bins = 15)+ labs(title = "Palmer Penguins Distribution of Flipper Length", x = "Flipper Length (mm)") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec03_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Bins = 25 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x=penguins$flipper_length_mm )) + geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "tomato1", bins = 25)+ labs(title = "Palmer Penguins Distribution of Flipper Length", x = "Flipper Length (mm)") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec03_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Bins = 35 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x=penguins$flipper_length_mm )) + geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "tomato1", bins = 35)+ labs(title = "Palmer Penguins Distribution of Flipper Length", x = "Flipper Length (mm)") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lec03_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ## Faceting {.scrollable .smaller} - Faceting is used to make the same plot for different subgroups of the dataset. - This is useful for comparing the same variable across different subgroups in the dataset. - `facet_wrap(~var)` can be added on to ANY plot type (scatterplot, linegraph, histogram, boxplot, barplot)
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x=flipper_length_mm)) + geom_histogram(color = "white", fill = "tomato1", bins = 11) + facet_wrap(~ species) ``` ::: ![](images_lecture/fig_03facet.png){#id .class width="800px" height="600px"} ## Common Coding Errors {.scrollable} ::: {.absolute top="0%" left="90%" width="100"} ![](images_lecture/participate_icon.png) ::: Which of the following are correct? a) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x=flipper_length_mm)) + geom_histogram(aes(color = "white")) ``` ::: b) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x=flipper_length_mm)) + geom_histogram(color = "white") ``` ::: c) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins) + geom_histogram(x = flipper_length_mm, color = "white") ``` ::: d) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins) + geom_histogram(aes(x = flipper_length_mm) , color = "white") ``` ::: ## Extra information and resources {.scrollable .smaller} [Wikipedia bin size info](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Histogram#Number_of_bins_and_width) Helpful guidelines: - Larger number of observations generally correspond to larger number of bins needed. - You will generally need to test **several** different number of bins to learn about the data and find an appropriate value. - Sturges Rule of Thumb for unimodal symmetric distributions: bins = 1 + 3.322\*log(n) - Sturge's rule is not great if the data is severely skewed, multi-modal, or for an extremely large number of observations. But it could give you a starting place and then you will want to increase the number of bins until you can properly see the shape.

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {

      // dispatch for htmlwidgets
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for reveal
    if (window.Reveal) {
      window.Reveal.addEventListener("slidechanged", function(event) {
        fireSlideChanged(event.previousSlide, event.currentSlide);
      });
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
